author: BigFace918907
body: Buy and hold. TSM manufacturers over 50% of the worlds semiconductors and sells to Apple, Nvidia, Qualcomm and other “chip producers”. Some of them are trying to build their own foundries but those are incredibly expensive and take a long time.

author: utalkin_tome
body:
People really need to understand that the competition isn't between ISAs like x86 and ARM. Both of these ISAs have borrowed from each others accomplishments to keep advancing.

The competition is between the design of the SoC itself. Apple engineers just designed a REALLY good chip using ARM license. They've been designing their own chips for a long time now so they have talent.

ARM by itself didn't provide some magical performance improvement. Look at Qualcomm and Samsung for a good example. Both use ARM to design their chips and they can barely compete with Apple's design.

AMD also uses x86 and has designed chips that can compete with Apple's designs and beat some of Intel's chips too. So again the competition is between the design itself and not the ISAs.

author: exe_virus
body:
Big tech will be regulated to hell. Maybe not now, not in 5 years. But it will be anti monopoly regulated until a new crop emerges and overtakes. 

Happened with AT&T bell in the 60's which led to IBM, AMD, Texas instruments, etc.

Then in the 80's/90's, antitrust threats is what led these large hardware companies to outsource their software OS to Microsoft and apple and Unix. 

Then in the 2000's we had Microsoft Monopoly broken up and the dot com crash, which led to Google, myspace, etc. Then in '08 google and Qualcomm and all these technologies came together to form what allowed today's JavaScript web based companies like Facebook, YouTube (google), linkedin (Microsoft) you get the idea. 

What has allowed big tech to stay on top is *acquisitions*. When that power is taken away, you will see big tech's investment thesis fall apart. And lo and behold that's the kind of anti monopoly regulations we are starting to see.

author: Vitadek_Gaming
body:
I work with a lot of satellite signal equipment.
The biggest issue with trying to get lots of "bandwidth" within satellite services is water, we call it "rain fade". Basically, you can get better and more robust signal at lower frequencies, but have a less medium to work with when sending data through.
At higher frequencies, water (rain/clouds) tend to interfere with the signal, but you can push more data through. But it's not as reliable. If you're using Ka band, and it starts raining, you're SOL.
So it's generally a give and take. Usually the answer is a better modem, what basically translates your signal to usable data. Certain equipment allows for more efficient symbol translation (Qualcomm has a good handle on this). As well as finding the best band for the mission/task. Better transceivers and receivers help too ofc. But it's hard to package solid sat lock into a phone, I'm curious on how they got around it.

Anyways, here's a good article: https://www.esa.int/Applications/Telecommunications_Integrated_Applications/Satellite_frequency_bands

You can't get "5G' from satellite, you can't even get half a mile with 5G telecommunication. 

But there you go, a break down of satellite service providers.

author: Investing8675309
body:
TSM put out 5nm last year and is ramping this year. Intel 10nm won’t be out until mid-fall. After that they’ll go to 7nm. 

To be fair this isn’t a nm-to-nm comparison, some have argued, rightfully so, that an Intel 7nm is comparative to a TSM 5nm. I believe AMD’s are still on 7nm (I’m not going to check this but going off memory). Intel has done a great job of improving their chips over the last few years without the nm shrinkage. That said, AMD has caught up.

There have been some interesting reports of Intel partnering on 3nm with TSM, not sure if that will go anywhere.

Keep in mind this isn’t just an Intel vs AMD/TSM. TSM supplies Apple, Qualcomm, and, really, just about everyone else.

author: cuteman
body:
>The bill negotiation process is what I was referring to. 
>
>But Republicans are responsible for a lot of things being so far behind. Would you like me to start naming them...

US lack of dominance in semi conductors isn't one of them.

That lands squarely on US companies who have failed to invest and chose to offshore production to their own peril.

If anything this reads like companies now need a bailout because of their failures to invest and innovate themselves over prior decades.

It's only because of the recent chip shortage and blatantly obvious disadvantages versus Asian fabs that there is motive for it to be suggested in the first place.

It's only because of the spending spree for anything and everything that a proposal of this type could even make it to a vote. 

If Amazon fell behind Alibaba should the government give them tens of billions in grants/loans to catch up?

These are some of the largest, and high margin companies we're talking about here: Intel, Qualcomm, etc.

I don't think it's a slam dunk not obvious what should happen.

author: Rodgerwilco
body:
TSMC supplies Apple, NVDA, Intel, AMD, Samsung, Qualcomm, IBM, Microsoft, Sony etcetcetcetc. They are responsible for over 70% of the words chips. Sure, we're investing in US production of chips but TSMC is strategic by keeping their most important/advanced nodes on mainland Taiwan.  

China wants Taiwan. USA and allies will back Taiwan because it's a matter of national security and it's in our best interest to not get fucked by China.  

You're right, TSMC the company is not monetarily 'worth' 5 Trillion right now. But what's the price tag of a country that 70% of the worlds chips rely on? What are the collective value of lives that will be lost over that war? It's worth more than 5T in my books.

author: LaLiLuLeLo_0
body:
ARM doesn't make CPUs, they license the ARM architecture that other companies (like Qualcomm or Apple) buy and make CPUs based on. My thinking is that NVDA will be licensing ARM to an increasing number of both Apple and non-Apple PC manufacturers.

Also, ARM use is [growing in the datacenter](https://www.digitimes.com/news/a20210302PD209.html) thanks to its lower power consumption. Nvidia GPUs are already the de-facto standard for datacenter machine learning applications, and if Nvidia were to own ARM, they could more tightly integrate both ARM CPUs and Nvidia GPUs, or combine the two on a high performance SoC, for much better performance.

author: somewhat_pragmatic
body:
>  There's basically an insatiable hunger for computing power going forward for at least the next 25 years.

25 years is a VERY long time in the world of semiconductor technology.  Nvidia and AMD are decently positioned with their GPU technologies.  Intel is not in a great position.  Their present day bread and butter is x86 CPUs used in laptops, desktops, and servers.  

Household purchase of desktop and laptop computers has declined precipitously in the last 10 years.  People are largely doing home computing on tablets and phones now.  Thats a huge chunk of lost Intel sales.  Additionally Apple is now producing laptops with ARM based CPUs further eroding Intel laptop sales in the remaining business market.

Intel's final solid ground was the server market.  Except AMD is now eating their lunch with their Epyc CPUs at the high end, and now at the low end ARM based CPUs are entering the server market.  Cloud provider AWS introduced the ARM based Graviton CPU for value cloud computing.  MS cloud provider is using Qualcomm ARM CPUs as a new product for low end computing on Azure.

So all of Intel's cash cows are under heavy attack without a clear answer from Intel about where their future revenue is going to come from.

author: ILoveMyFerrari
body:
Yeah, FB is a great stock. I bought some back when it dipped to $257 per share, and it's a damn shame that I got out of it in the 280's and went into something else, because it's had a really nice run into the 350's. I would have been better off just holding FB the entire time.

FB is certainly a wonderful stock to own, assuming you don't classify it almost as a "sin" stock like Phillip Morris or something. (Due to their heavy handed censorship and crowd psychology experiments)

I find their censorship tactics annoying, and they do lots of shady things, but it's the business world, so what do you expect? Altruism? lol. So, I'm not too bothered.

I want to get back into FB at some point, but I'm waiting on some sort of overall market correction. It's ran so much in the last couple of months, that I feel like I'd be buying back in at it's 2021 peak. Maybe around $320 ish, I could ease back in.

Regarding whether Facebook is fashionable or not, I'm actually not making any personal judgement calls on that. It's not that I think it's unfashionable. I actually don't have much of a personal opinion on it. I barely use the service, but it's not for that reason. However, I have lots of friends and associates that were heavy users of the platform, and they have since departed the platform. (not talking about Trump supporters either)  Of course, that's just anecdotal evidence, but when you see enough of it, it does ring some alarm bells.

Also, anybody that buys a Quest 2 is required to sign up for a Facebook account. There are tons and tons of complaints from Quest 2 owners that would prefer not to be "forced" to sign up with a social media platform just to use a headset. However, for Facebook, it's a great strategy, because when your user numbers are starting to chip off, you can add a whole bunch of new users that are only signing up because they're forced to with an Oculus 2 headset.

Even though many of these users will never use Facebook proper, it doesn't matter, because their numbers help make the ecosystem look healthier than it really is.

I'm not trying to say Facebook is the next MySpace or anything like that. I'm just trying to point out, that there are plenty of thorns on this rose as well. We can't just totally ignore them.

However, I'd like to get back to the original discussion on profiting in the VR and AR space. Those of us that know that VR and AR are going to be absolutely huge in the future, want to take advantage of this inside knowledge now, and invest in VR and AR companies that could really take off, when the general public at large is fully aware of all of this.

So, getting back to the idea of "pure" plays, are you aware of anything else that somebody should keep their eye on? I've done a fair amount of research on this topic, but there isn't a lot of obvious answers. There's a number of private companies that could become more interesting if they go public, but we can't really worry about them until that actually happens. If we want to stick with publicly traded companies, the ones that best fit the profile are Kopin Corporation, Microvision, Vuzix Corporation, eMagin Corporation, HTC, Snapchat.

Personally, I'd avoid HTC as their management is absolutely awful. I'm not very bullish on Snapchat either, but had to mention them, because they have longterm AR ambitions. I just think they'll be squashed by the true power players. Other stocks to consider that will benefit off a VR/AR revolution potentially is NVDA, AMD, QCOM, TSM (supposedly making some chips for Apple's upcoming VR HMD), Samsung, SONY.

I'm always looking for some other stocks in this segment that I'm not currently aware of.

author: p_giggles
body:
You are overestimating bitcoin's impact on the broader semiconductor market. Last time bitcoin shit the bed in 2017 NVDA was the only company affected by it.  Companies making datacenter switches (AVGO) or PC CPUs (INTC) or mobile basebands (QCOM) or analog chips (TXN) do not care about crypto because their parts aren't used for it. 

I'm not sure who you're referencing by "all the suppliers." Are you referring to GPU suppliers? Because it's NVDA with a little bit of AMD.

author: stickman07738
body:
**Get out when you have achieved your target and take re-entry after 4 weeks minimum ----> Locking profits**

**I agree with taking profits** but I would not get out and re-buy.   My strategy is at 25% growth take some profits; if it hits 50% over my purchase price - sell 1/3 or 1/2 dependent on the stock and let the free shares ride.  If you exit, you may be buying share at a higher price. 

You also need to have an exit strategy to control your downside risk.  I never understood averaging down (catching a falling knife).  If a stock goes down by 15%, I sell and watch.  I ask myself what did I miss?  If it starts behaving as my earlier analyses expected, I may buy back in.  (I learned this lesson the hard way during dot-com bubble with QCOM - thought I was genius buying on the dip, only to eventually lose $300K.)

author: pigsgetfathogsdie
body:
I had friends who became paper multi-millionaires from a fukkin greetingcard.com company…then…poof…lost it all.

Multiply the above by a few thousand totally shady tech IPOs.

From Wiki…was totally mental…

Between 1995 and its peak in March 2000, the Nasdaq Composite stock market index rose 400%, only to fall 78% from its peak by October 2002, giving up all its gains during the bubble. During the crash, many online shopping companies, such as Pets.com, Webvan, and Boo.com, as well as several communication companies, such as Worldcom, NorthPoint Communications, and Global Crossing, failed and shut down.

Some companies, such as Cisco, whose stock declined by 86%, Amazon.com, and Qualcomm, lost a large portion of their market capitalization but survived.

author: mitttttch
body:
What has better growth potential moving forward? 

AMD or Qualcomm?

I really like what AMD is doing in terms of technology and contracts.(gaming consoles, interface for automobiles, pc gaming)

but it's hard to ignore Qualcomm patents and hold it has in the mobile industry. Mobile, I think, has bigger room for growth. With 5g, and emerging country's still getting mobile devices. 

Any insight would be greatly appreciated. (I also feel like $MU might be a good time to jump in but that's another story). Any .2 is more then welcome !

body: Qualcomm printing like a mofo. Time to buy quality growth again.

author: Bouvill
body: Indeed, XLNX is a nice play, but AMD has a very nice potential for short+long term, so I'm all in AMD since this morning

author: OneTrueZach
body:
Yes! I forgot about that. The first one since 2001 and for a whopping $4 billion. My understanding is that they are just trying to control the number of shareholders as they complete their merger with Xilinx. 

Edit: Link is banned. Look for the SA article from 5/20/21 "AMD Stock Buyback a Strong Signal"

author: justsomescrub
body:
Not so much diversifying as just straight up killing it. Operating income rose 189% from 2019 to 2020 with eps up 604%. Q1 2021 operating income is up 266% and eps is up 232% from Q1 2020 and it isn't *just* higher margins; Total revenue in 2020 was up 45% from 2019 and Q1 2021 total rev Is up 92% compared to Q1 2020. Oh and the XLNX acquisition or whatever pending china approval.

  
AND there are some tasty insider whispers IF TRUE insinuating next gen GPU performance above and beyond what they expect from Nvidia. FULL STOP. Not at bargain price points, or for certain niche applications just straight up expecting to have the best GPUs on the market next gen. Nvidia having something spicy up their sleeve non-withstanding; you never know with Nvidia.   

  Add in plans to buy back 4 billion worth of shares over the next 4(?) Years with cash on hand and plans for 3nm production by 2024 and everything I hear about AMD makes me think up up up. They have new deals with Samsung for their phones and google/amazon for servers, to add to the pile of deals like making chips for Sony and Microsoft consoles. The future looks bright.

I put 90% of my account in AMD last month when they were hovering around 80$ without a single worry and I haven't unwound my position yet. Hoping for 2021 guidance to be adjusted from 50% to 75% growth to set this thing off again. Or merger approval, whatever comes first.

author: Protoculture_11
body:
XLNX dumps if china block since AMD paid huge premium to acquire it. 

My concern is China block this if US/UK blocks ARM/NVDA. 

From China's perspective, they have no reason absent external factors to block AMD/Xilinx. 

Still not a bad arbitrage play to buy Xilinx though. I just prefer to hold AMD to ensure gains are locked in without relying on a merger to get approved.

author: MaxJones123
body: Dilution and merger downsides were priced in as soon as they announced it. Note that Xilinx is a good EPS positive company anyways. AMD is probably just gonna rocket up until earnings if the market is good

author: TheTendilorian
body: Xilinx will be worth 1.7 AMD share price or something  like that. Multiply amd by 1.7whatever and if it's higher than xilinx share price at deal closing then you'll make extra money but if xilinx runs past that multiplied amount you'll loose money

author: Phaiiroh
body:
AMD shareholders have agreed to acquire XLNX. Instead of paying with cash, they are acquiring the company entirely through stock. The two parties have agreed to a fixed ratio of 1:1.72 to do so. Meaning for every one share of XLNX owned you will receive 1.72 ish shares of AMD. Only if all necessary regulatory bodies approve the acquisition. Currently China is the last approval required until the merger can occur. Technically China can say no and AMD will most likely decide to not go on with the merger.

Because the acquisition is a fixed rate of shares. OP is staring at current market prices the value of one share of XLNX currently is cheaper than 1.72 shares of AMD creating a small discount. So if you were to buy XLNX in an attempt to buy AMD at a cheaper rate it could or could not possibly work out. It’s not a guaranteed thing.

author: FelixJuggl3r
body: Make the whole sub believe you are directly controlled by the CCP. I would be ok with it as far as AMD gets approval for the merger with Xilinx.

author: StuartMcNight
body:
If the deal is blocked XLNX will tank heavily in the short term while AMD is likely to remain almost untouched. That’s why the premium is there.

Source of the problem is the Same reason why BABA, BIDU or JD have significantly lower valuations than the US equivalents. Unpredictability of China increases the risks.

author: MastersParadox
body: Waiting for China to approve AMD merger with Xilinx. AMD gonna breakout like crazy when it gets approved!! 🚀

author: Runningflame570
body:
Their competitive position is getting better with every Intel delay and increase in available capacity at TSMC. No real price target here, but they're well worth buying still.

About the only thing that could realistically prevent further appreciation over the next year or two is if China blocks the Xilinx merger.

Maybe I'm missing something tho, I'd really like someone with more experience than me to comment on this whole thing.

author: TheTendilorian
body: Until xilinx passes that multiplier threshold

author: stevoacp1
body: i love $AMD, however comparing them to NVDA is not the right move. NVDA is a different beast in that they have the growth of AMD while having the stellar gross margins. Investors are willing to pay a premium for NVDA because of how stellar they are in printing cash and profits. That being said, AMD deserves to be priced closer to NVDA than Intel. I do not believe AMD and Su Bae are focused on catching NVDA, and are more concerned with taking market share from and crushing Intel. All the DDs written on here continue to ignore how important the Xilinx merger is. It was hated on by many, but Su Bae is no moron, she is strongly positioning AMD to dominate the CPU and Semi-Custom solutions. AMD will continue to make progress in the GPU and gaming market but the growth and tendies will come from expanding further into and dominating the server industry and building strong relationships that will establish profits for years, as well as expansion into 5g, aerospace and defense, and AI.

author: rodmcmuffins
body: I don't understand the value here. The stock price is already high and now they're significantly diluting the shares by overpaying for Xilinx.   AMD will probably keep climbing, but good lord that's a high price compared to earnings.

author: ScoopYourPoop
body: When/if China approves the XLNX merger, AMD should get a nice bump. Otherwise, you’re right about TSM. Seems to be held down by threat of China invading Taiwan but that is quite unlikely….

author: mn_sunny
body:
I added shares of XLNX around $115 (AMD equivalent of ~$73) back in May and it was the first time I added to my AMD position since the Covid bottoms (all of the rest of my shares were from 2016 and 2018).

I think AMD is valued more conservatively than the vast majority of other tech/semi companies, but I still think it's ahead of itself. I wouldn't buy it at these current levels, but I'm definitely not selling either (e.g. - I told my family it was safe to buy in May when it got down in the low 70s, but said not to buy above $78-80).

Peter Lynch would approve though given it's EPS growth % is greater than (or equal to) it's P/E multiple.

Do a deep dive of r/amd_stock if you're really interested in AMD--there's a lot of excellent content and some extremely informed people there (I honestly don't follow AMD like I used to b/c I have enough faith in Su/Kumar/Papermaster/Norrod/Wang/etc that I'm just letting my AMD ride and spending all of my time focusing on the rest of my portfolio).

author: CoVLifter
body: No idea. Check out xlnx. Massive dump and now it’s halted. Amd and nvda dumped too

author: Huff0341
body:
Ultimately yes you are correct. The reason for the spread though is the risk involved if the merger doesn’t go through. While most hurdles have been passed I believe they still have China and the US to work through. It’ll tighten up the closer to the merger it gets assuming the hurdles all get jumped. It’s also one of the reasons AMD isn’t popping as much. A lot of  arbiters will short the Buying Company and buy up the target. 

I have not shorted AMD, but I am in on XLNX. Might double my position as I think the risk is worth the it.

author: the_dean_list
body: Yeah today I closed out some $AMD OTM leaps I bought at $75 and made some decent money on with this latest run up to $94. I was thinking with the Xilinx merger upcoming and most likely what will be positive earnings, it makes sense to open up some ITM leaps and sell covered calls whenever the market or stock is trading laterally. I’m pretty bullish on the stock; I think it’ll definitely hit $120s by next year if the merger is approved.

author: avl0
body: Love how this acquisition was announced 9 months ago and WSB has only just realised there's arbitrage  value in owning Xilinx

author: Latter-Bodybuilder33
body: The goal would be to reach a comparable market cap.. share price by itself is not a comparable metric. AMD is about 1/5th of NVDA in market cap.. and it would have to essentially fire on all cylinders in some kind of volume growth segment: AI, Autonomous, Crypto to get be in same ballpark as NVDA... not only through product pipeline but also getting folks to wean off of comparable nvda products. The xlnx acquisition may increase AMD’s TAM but Nvidia is still king in many segments.. I would be surprised if any of that rapid amd growth happens before 3-4 years ..

author: RabidRabb1t
body: XLNX free money when merger completes

author: lefty_vengeance
body:
What reason do you think this will moon.  I expect it was showing nice gains mostly because Xilinx merger felt imminent.  With today's news of China moving forward with phase 2 review, people are going to be much more inclined to take profits:

"SAMR's process involves up to three review periods: Phase One lasts 30 days, Phase Two lasts 60 days, and Phase Three lasts 90 days. The regulator decides at the end of each phase if it's ready to make a decision or if it will move on to the next phase."

So rather than thumbs up, we've got up to 60 days before China gives the go ahead (or delays another 3 fucking months if they so choose).

I don't see it starting to heat back up until a few weeks after earnings.  I predict it sees low 80s before then.

author: rodmcmuffins
body:
AMD has been looking very promising lately, but it still faces the problem of massive dilution after the future Xilinx merger. The $34 billion all stock purchase far outweighs the $4 billion buyback. AMD has value, but it is already expensive before the dilution even with significant revenue growth factored in.  They aren't pulling the margins that could justify a large jump in share price.

Who knows though, an irrational market like ours will probably eat this up anyway.

author: ConditionPrudent1648
body:
I totally recommend leaps options.

Firstly, I made most of my money from leaps.
Share price rises by 25%, my options will have at least 50% profit margin.

Secondly, my holding timeline for stocks is usually 6-12 months. So leaps is great for me 
For my kids, I will buy stocks as I am leaving it for them for the next 15-20 years.

Lastly, don't think u can use margin on options so it prevents me from over leveraging.

PS. I usually sell my options once it get 50% profit margin and move on. Reason is that for me to get 100% profit on options, I will need the stock to rise at least 40-50% which is not really realistic, especially when I have time decay playing against me.

I also buy leaps options on solid companies like Google, amazon, xlnx, baba, jd, Shopify, ttd, crm......etc
I try not to play with meme stocks or companies that do not show at least 4 quarters of profitability.

Best of luck!

author: ConditionPrudent1648
body:
I had some pretty decent results doing leaps call options.
Usually buy ATM call options expiring 200 days and above.

Usually chose blue chip companies that are stable.
Like apple, Shopify, amazon, crm, tsmc, xlnx etc....
Minimum requirement is that the company should be profitable for at least 4 quarters with 15% and above profit margin. These companies tend to rise slowly and steadily with time, so your longer expiration will give it time to play the senerio out 

A 10% rise in stock price will usually translate to a 20% options gain for u. And a 30% stick price increase will translate to a 50% gain for u.

Try to avoid meme stocks and new spac companies and volatile companies as their sudden movement downwards will mean much greater depreciation for your options also. Example, a 30% drop in share price will translate to a 50% drop in your options price.

Every leaps options I have bought till now will be profitable some point in time. U just need to prevent greed and exit accordingly.
Suggestion is to exit around the 50% profit mark or when the option is near the half way mark. Reason is that there is time decay associated with call options, so keeping it to expiry or keeping it too long is disadvantageous to you.

Best of luck!

author: Wyzrobe
body:
I'm way overweight on AMD (and XLNX too, for the merger premium).  

But I would not consider it a forever stock. Technological shifts can change everything in a moment, just a few years ago INTC seemed like a forever stock, and all that's changed with AMD's rise.
